metadata.case_name: Appellants (Wife and Sons of Daulatram Hukamchand) v. Official Assignee

facts.text: Daulatram Hukamchand executed a deed of gift on May 22, 1950, in favour of his wife and three sons (appellants).
Some creditors of Daulatram filed a petition in Bombay High Court, Insolvency Case No. 74 of 1951, after he gave notice of suspension of payment of debts on August 2, 1951.
Daulatram adjudicated insolvent on August 21, 1951; estate vested in official assignee under s.17 Presidency Towns Insolvency Act.
Official assignee (respondent) took notice of motion on September 26, 1951, under s.55 for declaration that deed of gift void.
Appellants 1 to 3 filed joint affidavit claiming deed not a gift but transaction supported by valuable consideration, not within s.55.
Before Mr. Justice Coyajee: Respondent objected to appellants' oral evidence under s.92 Evidence Act; overruled, evidence led; Judge rejected contention, declared deed void on January 28, 1954.
Appellants appealed (Appeal No. 30 of 1954) to Bombay High Court; Chagla C.J. and Shah J. held evidence inadmissible under s.92, dismissed appeal on August 6, 1954.
High Court rejected certificate on September 23, 1954; Supreme Court granted special leave on November 3, 1954.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellants entitled to lead oral evidence to show real nature of impugned transaction (deed of gift actually supported by valuable consideration), considering true scope and effect of ss.91 and 92 Evidence Act, and applicability to proceedings under s.55 Presidency Towns Insolvency Act where official assignee challenges transfer.
Whether official assignee is representative-in-interest of insolvent in s.55 proceedings, making s.92 applicable between official assignee and donees.

petitioner_arguments.text: Document purported to be gift but really transaction supported by valuable consideration, not falling within mischief of s.55 Presidency Towns Insolvency Act.

respondent_arguments.text: Evidence inadmissible under s.92 Evidence Act to contradict terms of deed of gift executed out of natural love and affection by showing valuable consideration.

court_reasoning.text: ss.91 and 92 Evidence Act supplement each other; s.91 excludes oral evidence of document contents (best evidence rule); s.92 excludes oral agreements contradicting/varying terms of dispositive documents between parties/representatives in interest.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.92 applies only between parties to instrument or representatives in interest; strangers not bound.

court_reasoning.text: Official assignee not representative-in-interest of insolvent under s.55; acts for creditors' benefit, not insolvent; property already transferred out; higher title than insolvent; proceedings annul transactions for creditors.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Official assignee like creditor who can challenge under s.55 (with indemnity) or s.54A Provincial Act; s.92 inapplicable.

court_reasoning.text: Appellants (donees, representatives in interest) can lead evidence vs stranger (official assignee); no mutuality; s.99 clarifies strangers/third parties can vary terms; s.91 not exclude oral agreement varying terms if s.92 inapplicable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.92 rule of exclusion based on mutuality; inequitable against party vs stranger.

holdings.text: s.92 Evidence Act wholly inapplicable to proceedings between official assignee and donees under s.55 Presidency Towns Insolvency Act; appellants entitled to lead oral evidence on real nature of transaction.
Official assignee not representative-in-interest of insolvent in s.55 proceedings.

precedents_cited.relevance: Extrinsic evidence excluded only between parties/privies, not party and stranger; no mutuality.

statutes_cited.name: Presidency Towns Insolvency Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Adjudication vests estate in official assignee; transfers voidable by official assignee if within 2 years, except for marriage/valuable consideration in good faith.

statutes_cited.name: Provincial Insolvency Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Similar provisions for voidable transfers by receiver/creditor; supports official assignee not acting for insolvent.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Exclusion of oral evidence for document terms (s.91); oral agreements varying dispositive documents between parties (s.92); third parties/strangers may show contemporaneous varying agreement (s.99).

outcome.summary: Supreme Court set aside Bombay High Court judgment dismissing appeal (which held evidence inadmissible under s.92), as s.92 inapplicable; remanded appeal to Bombay High Court for disposal on merits in accordance with law.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed; case remanded to Bombay High Court for decision on merits of oral evidence.

key_quotes.text: the official assignee... acts not for the insolvent or on his behalf, but in the interest of the whole body of the insolvents creditors.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key to holding official assignee not representative-in-interest.

key_quotes.text: s.92 cannot apply to the present proceedings between the respondent and the appellants and so there can be no doubt that the respondent would not be precluded from leading evidence of an oral agreement...
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The rule of exclusion enunciated by s.92 applies to both parties to the document and is based on the doctrine of mutuality.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why s.92 inapplicable vs stranger.
